title: Logical Operators (Combining Conditions)
simplifierConcept:
Sometimes you need to check MULTIPLE conditions:

   - It's summer OR pool is heated
   
ðŸš— Can't drive IF:
   - NOT has license

Three logical operators:

&& = AND (both must be true)
|| = OR (at least one must be true)
! = NOT (flips true/false)

Truth tables:
AND (&&): T && T = T, everything else = F
OR (||): F || F = F, everything else = T
NOT (!): !T = F, !F = T

Think: Logical operators let you combine multiple yes/no questions!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: AND operator. Both sides must be TRUE for result to be TRUE. if (a && b) means a AND b must both be true. If either is false, whole thing is false.
OR operator. At least one side must be TRUE for result to be TRUE. if (a || b) means a OR b (or both) must be true. Only false if BOTH are false.
NOT operator. Flips boolean value. !true becomes false. !false becomes true. if (!condition) runs when condition is FALSE. Like 'if not'.
AND (&&) stops checking if first is false (result already known). OR (||) stops if first is true. if (x != 0 && 10/x > 2) is safe - won't divide by zero!

challenge.instructions:
Create a smart thermostat controller!

1. Ask for current temperature
2. Ask if it's daytime (true/false)
3. Ask if someone is home (true/false)
4. Control heating/cooling based on rules:

   Turn ON heat if:
   - Temp < 18 AND someone is home
   OR
   - Temp < 15 (always, even if away)
   
   Turn ON AC if:
   - Temp > 26 AND (it's daytime OR someone is home)
   
   Otherwise:
   - System off (comfortable)

5. Display the action taken and why

challenge.hint: Use && for conditions that must BOTH be true. Use || for conditions where AT LEAST ONE must be true. Combine with parentheses: (a && b) || c means (a AND b) OR c.
commonStickingPoints: Confusing && and ||: && needs BOTH true. || needs AT LEAST ONE true. if (age > 18 && age < 65) for range. if (role == \"admin\" || role == \"mod\") for options.
Forgetting parentheses: a && b || c is confusing! Use (a && b) || c to be clear. && has higher precedence than || but don't rely on it - use parentheses!
Using & or | instead of && or ||: Single & is bitwise operator (different!). Always use && for AND logic, || for OR logic in conditions.
Double NOT: if (!!condition) is valid but confusing! !!true = true, !!false = false. Just use if (condition)! Double NOT does nothing useful here.
